Composite Signals Report

Generated on: November 29, 2025 at 09:12 PM

Overarching Recommendation

Overarching Recommendation: Macroeconomic Synthesis & Narrative

As of: November 30, 2025 | Coverage: Late 2024 through November 2025

Scope reflects all signals provided in this run; structure is invariant to new or removed inputs.

1) Executive Summary (≤ 120 words)

The macroeconomic landscape reflects a cautious but easing environment. Disinflationary pressures are evident (US Inflation, MIIE), supported by a softening labor market (LMT, Labor Turnover, Employment Comp). Liquidity is expanding (Fed Liquidity), despite ongoing quantitative tightening, and the USD is weakening. However, deeply bearish consumer sentiment (UMich Sentiment) and rising financial stress (Financial Stress Index) temper overall optimism. The inverted yield curve (Treasury Yield Curve) signals potential future slowdowns. This composite points to a defensive tilt, favoring duration and precious metals, while equities face headwinds despite some durable goods strength.

  • Disinflationary Slowdown
  • Easing Financial Conditions with Underlying Stress
  • Risk-Off Bias, Favoring Duration & Defensives

3) Dominant Themes

  • The labor market shows increasing slack and decelerating dynamism, contributing to a disinflationary environment (Labor, Wage Growth, US Inflation).
  • Despite ongoing quantitative tightening, substantial liquidity easing is driven by declining overnight reverse repo usage (Fed Liquidity, M2 Money Supply).
  • Pervasive bearish consumer sentiment and elevated financial stress continue to signal a risk-off environment (UMich Sentiment, Financial Stress Index).
  • The inverted yield curve and stabilizing real rates suggest market anticipation of future growth slowdowns and potential monetary easing (Treasury Yield Curve, Real Interest Rate).
  • Core manufacturing exhibits positive momentum, contrasting with a neutral overall industrial production and sectoral employment breadth (Durable Goods, Industrial Production, Sectoral Employment).

4) Cross-Signal Interactions

Explain how signals reinforce or offset each other. Prioritize causal or historically reliable linkages.

  • Softening labor markets (Labor Turnover, Employment Comp.) combined with moderating wage growth (Wage Growth) reinforces the disinflationary trend (US Inflation, MIIE).
  • Easing liquidity (Fed Liquidity, M2) is largely driven by declining ON RRP usage, partially offsetting the balance sheet run-off effects.
  • An inverted yield curve (Treasury Yield Curve) coinciding with elevated financial stress (Financial Stress Index) increases the probability of an economic downturn, per historical relationships.
  • Weakening USD (USD Index) generally supports precious metals, while deeply bearish consumer sentiment (UMich Sentiment) further boosts safe-haven demand.
  • Bullish durable goods orders (Durable Goods) provide some resilience, but neutral industrial production (Industrial Production) and slowing sectoral employment breadth (Sectoral Employment) indicate broader growth challenges.

5) Regime Assessment

Current Regime: Disinflationary Slowdown with Financial Caution

Evidence: Labor market indicators (Labor, LMT) show increasing slack. Inflation signals (US Inflation, MIIE) are cool/stable. Financial stress (Financial Stress Index) is elevated, and consumer sentiment (UMich Sentiment) is bearish. The yield curve (Treasury Yield Curve) remains inverted, historically signaling economic deceleration.

Historical Analogue(s): Periods preceding mild recessions or significant growth slowdowns, such as specific phases in the late 1990s or mid-2000s, characterized by slowing labor and inflation without acute financial crisis.

6) Asset-Class Implications (Evidence-Linked)

  • Equities: Cautious stance due to softening labor (Labor), bearish consumer sentiment (UMich Sentiment), and elevated financial stress (Financial Stress Index); however, easing liquidity (Fed Liquidity) provides some tailwinds. Tilt: UW.
  • Bonds/Duration: Bullish, supported by persistent disinflationary trends (US Inflation, MIIE), a softening labor market (LMT), and an inverted yield curve (Treasury Yield Curve) anticipating rate cuts. Tilt: OW.
  • Credit: Neutral outlook. Spreads remain in a normal regime (Credit Spread), suggesting moderate funding stress. Monitor for broader financial stress (Financial Stress Index) to avoid tightening. Tilt: Neutral.
  • FX (USD): Bearish. The USD Index shows a weakening trend below its 12-month average, which typically reflects easing global financial conditions. Tilt: UW.
  • Commodities/Metals: Precious metals are bullish due to a weakening USD (USD Index) and safe-haven demand (UMich Sentiment, Financial Stress). Industrial metals are neutral-to-bearish due to mixed industrial production (Industrial Production). Tilt: OW Precious, Neutral Industrial.
  • Other (if applicable): No tilt for other asset classes based on the provided signals.

State directional tilts (e.g., OW/UW/Neutral) only where the evidence is clear; otherwise say “no tilt.”

8) Risk Checks & Contradictions

  • Strong liquidity expansion (Fed Liquidity, ON RRP -96.17% YoY) conflicts with ongoing quantitative tightening (Fed Total Assets -5.11% YoY), creating ambiguity about systemic liquidity.
  • Bullish durable goods orders (Durable Goods +3.07% YoY) contradict the neutral overall industrial production (Industrial Production +0.84% YoY) and declining sectoral breadth.
  • Low market volatility (VIX returning to Normal) appears inconsistent with elevated financial stress (Financial Stress Index Bearish, Stress_z 1.70).
  • Neutral real interest rates (Real Interest Rate Neutral) with a deeply inverted yield curve (Treasury Yield Curve Bullish/inverted) imply differing views on future growth and inflation outlooks.
  • Wage growth moderation (Wage Growth, LMT Neutral) remains above levels typically associated with deep disinflation, indicating potential stickiness in labor costs.

Confidence Score (0–100): 70
